thread.title: Brit ISIS suicide bomber given £1 MILLION of taxpayers' money
thread.title_full: Brit ISIS suicide bomber given £1 MILLION of taxpayers' money

title: Brit ISIS suicide bomber given £1 MILLION of taxpayers' money
text:
PH/GETTY FIDDLER GOOF: Brit bomber was released from terror prison and given £1 million compensation 
The bomber, who ISIS named Abu Zakariya al-Britani, detonated an explosives filled vehicle close to Mosul , the terror group claimed. 
The 50-year-old, also known as Ronald Fiddler and Jamal Udeen, was previously arrested in the US after being suspected of terrorism. 
But after lobbying the British government, Fiddler was freed only to commit a terror offence 13 years later. ISIS's Dirty Dozen: Jihadi death cult's commanders Friday, 28th October 2016 A comprehensive compilation of the leadership of the Islamic State (IS) in pictures. 1 / 14 “The UK has advised for some time against all travel to Syria, and against all travel to large parts of Iraq” Foreign Office 
Fiddler was allegedly tortured for information at the infamous Guantanamo Bay , and was award £1 million in compensation from the government. 
When he was captured by US soldiers invading Afghanistan, he claimed he was travelling to nearby Iran when he was captured by the Taliban. 
The Mancunian has originally travelled to terror hotspot Pakistan in 2001 in what he claimed was a religious holiday. 
GETTY NOTORIOUS: Guantanamo houses some of the world's worst criminals 
After being released in 2004, he pledged allegiance to ISIS 10 years later. 
According to government figures, around 850 people have travelled to Iraq to join the war on terror, and just under half of those have returned to the UK. 
Security experts have said one of the largest risks to the UK's safety is returning radicalised terrorists committing atrocities on home soil . 
A Foreign Office spokesman said: "The UK has advised for some time against all travel to Syria, and against all travel to large parts of Iraq. 
"As all UK consular services are suspended in Syria and greatly limited in Iraq, it is extremely difficult to confirm the whereabouts and status off British nationals in these areas ." Related articles
